articles.headline: Drug Makers, in Shift, Join Fight Against Doping
articles.snippet: Pharmaceutical companies are helping to develop tests for illicit use in order to keep their offerings from being abused by athletes.
articles.abstract: Pharmaceutical companies are helping to develop tests for illicit use in order to keep their offerings from being abused by athletes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The blood-enhancing drug EPO has improved the lives of millions of anemia patients, but Lance Armstrong and other top cyclists have turned the medicine into a byword for doping.

articles.headline: Pro-Gun Lawmakers Are Open to Limits on Size of Magazines
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in both parties view an assault weapons ban as politically toxic, but many seem more amenable to restricting the kinds of high-capacity devices used in recent rampages.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in both parties view an assault weapons ban as politically toxic, but many seem more amenable to restricting the kinds of high-capacity devices used in recent rampages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Christopher S. Murphy, Democrat of Connecticut, is haunted by many things that emerged from the investigation of the December mass shooting at a Newtown elementary school. Among them is the nagging question of what prompted the gunman, Adam Lanza, to put down his rifle after killing 20 children and pick up the pistol he used to end his own life.

articles.headline: Morgan Stanley Strives to Coordinate 2 Departments Often at Odds
articles.snippet: Pressure mounts to coax greater profits from the low-margin brokerage business by finding ways for retail and investment banking to work better together.
articles.abstract: Pressure mounts to coax greater profits from the low-margin brokerage business by finding ways for retail and investment banking to work better together.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several hundred Morgan Stanley retail branch managers descended on the JW Marriott Orlando Grande Lakes resort in Florida early this month for a retreat. They were greeted by an unlikely colleague, Colm Kelleher, who runs the company’s sales and trading and investment banking departments.

articles.headline: A Reputation, Once Sullied, Acquires a New Shine
articles.snippet: Steven L. Rattner’s re-emergence as a power player is well under way.
articles.abstract: Steven L. Rattner’s re-emergence as a power player is well under way.
articles.lead_paragraph: How do you describe Steven L. Rattner?

articles.headline: Prosecutors, Shifting Strategy, Build New Wall Street Cases
articles.snippet: In prosecuting big banks, the government is starting to push for guilty pleas, rather than just the usual fines and reforms, a tactic expected to face roadblocks.
articles.abstract: In prosecuting big banks, the government is starting to push for guilty pleas, rather than just the usual fines and reforms, a tactic expected to face roadblocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Criticized for letting Wall Street off the hook after the financial crisis, the Justice Department is building a new model for prosecuting big banks.

articles.headline: Chinese Army Unit Is Seen as Tied to Hacking Against U.S.
articles.snippet: An overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American companies and government agencies start in a building on the edge of Shanghai, say cybersecurity experts and American intelligence officials.
articles.abstract: An overwhelming percentage of the attacks on American companies and government agencies start in a building on the edge of Shanghai, say cybersecurity experts and American intelligence officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Shanghai, in a run-down neighborhood dominated by a 12-story white office tower, sits a People’s Liberation Army base for China’s growing corps of cyberwarriors.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, David Barboza and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Nestlé Removes  2 Products in Horse Meat Scandal
articles.snippet: Nestlé, one of the world’s best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.
articles.abstract: Nestlé, one of the world’s best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — First centered on Britain and Ireland, the scandal over beef products adulterated with horse meat escalated across Continental Europe on Tuesday after Nestlé, one of the world’s best-known food companies, said it was removing pasta meals from store shelves in Italy and Spain.
